Is there any tool/API or automated way to sync the excel sheet data with deployed artifacts.

Thanks.

entry.title: How to carry HTTP error response payloads (e.g., 400, 401) from HTTP_AAE to ABAP server in SOAP-HTTP
entry.content:
Hi,

I am working on a simple integration scenario in SAP PO/PI, and I would appreciate your guidance on how to handle HTTP error payload propagation to the ABAP server.

Scenario:

  • Sender: ABAP system (S/4HANA)

    • Adapter: SOAP Sender

  • Receiver: External HTTP-based API (https://example.com/api)

    • Adapter: HTTP_AAE Receiver

This scenario works perfectly fine when the request payload is valid — the response from the external system is returned to the ABAP system as expected.

Problem:

When the ABAP system sends an invalid request payload (e.g., malformed JSON), the external system responds with an HTTP error status code, such as 400 (Bad Request), along with an error payload/message in the response body.

However:

  • The HTTP_AAE adapter handles these error status codes internally and does not propagate the error payload back to the ABAP server.

  • Instead, the message fails within PO, and the ABAP system does not receive the external system’s error response body, which we would like to see for debugging or logging purposes on the ABAP side.

Attempted Solution:

I created a custom adapter module in hope to access the exception generated within the standard sap.com/com.sap.aii.adapter.http/HttpAdapterBean module and process it accordingly. However, I observed that in the HTTP_AAE adapter’s module chain:

  • The sap.com/com.sap.aii.adapter.http/HttpAdapterBean standard module executes the HTTP call and immediately fails the processing upon receiving an error status code.

  • As a result, any custom module placed after sap.com/com.sap.aii.adapter.http/HttpAdapterBean in the chain does not execute when the HTTP call fails.

This seems to limit the ability to intercept and propagate the error payload to the ABAP server.

Question:

What is the recommended way to achieve the following:
In case of an HTTP error status code (e.g., 400, 401), still capture the external system’s response body and propagate it back to the ABAP server through the synchronous SOAP response?

Specifically:

  • Is there a standard configuration option in HTTP_AAE Adapter to pass the error response back?

  • If not, what is the correct way to extend or override the behavior of the sap.com/com.sap.aii.adapter.http/HttpAdapterBean to allow this?

  • Is writing a custom adapter from scratch really necessary in this case?

Any guidance, best practices, or example implementations would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Syed Ijlal Ayub

entry.title: does sap rest adapter(sender channel) in rest polling only read 1 message per poll from a queue
entry.content:
hi experts

I have a Rest Sender channel in Rest Polling mode reading from a ASB (Azure Service Bus) queue via Http endpoint. I am using SAP PO 7.5

i have observed that it reads only one message per poll from queue even though there are multiple messages to read. e.g. if there are 10 messages in queue and channel is polling every 10 seconds, it reads one message in first poll, then 2nd message after 10 seconds and so on. To read all 10 messages it takes 10 polls and 60 seconds in total.

Does the REST adapter work this way? or Is there a way to read all the available messages in queue at once using Rest adapter in Rest Polling mode?

Please suggest or if there is any standard guide which I can refer will be helpful.

Thanks.

Best Regards,

Nidhi Srivastava

entry.title: SAP PO WSSE Security in SOAP adapter
entry.content:
Hi
I am using the SOAP receiver adapter in SAP PO. The webservice i consume needs the Username and Password in the Soap Header like this:

	<soap:Header>
        <wsse:Security soap:mustUnderstand="1" xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd">
            <wsse:UsernameToken>
                <wsse:Username>xxx</wsse:Username>
                <wsse:Password>yyy</wsse:Password>
            </wsse:UsernameToken>
        </wsse:Security>
      </soap:Header>

How do i do that?

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration - Best approach to connect SAP PO 7.5 to CPI HTTPS endpoint with CSRF enabled
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We have a requirement to connect from SAP PO 7.5 (using the REST adapter) to a CPI HTTPS endpoint where CSRF protection is enabled.
Our goal is to achieve this integration with minimal changes to the existing SAP PO iFlow.

  • What is the recommended approach to handle the CSRF token in this scenario?

  • Is it necessary to implement an Async-Sync Bridge on the PO side, or are there more efficient alternatives to manage the token exchange?

Any guidance, best practices, or references would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance,

Niranjan Nayak

entry.title: Unable to deploy Function Library while Migrating from SAP PO to SAP CPI
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

While working on a B2B migration from SAP PO to SAP CPI, I am adding the Mapping and relevant Function library connecting to ESR and it is imported successfully. Mapping is deployed but the function library deployment is failing with the below error -

[CONTENT][CONTENT_DEPLOY][GenerationFailed] : The generation and build of the artifact were unsuccessful. Please address the issues outlined below and redeploy the artifact. Generation and build failed for B2B_Migration_Function_Library as validation of resource is failed Validation failed for the method concatTwoQueuesToOne defined in the Java class UDFNodePool.java. When the executionType is ALL_VALUES_OF_CONTEXT, there must be at least 3 arguments of which the last argument must always be of type Container and the second last must always be a ResultList. Validation failed for the method createContextsForFixedBlockSize defined in the Java class UDFNodePool.java. When the executionType is ALL_VALUES_OF_CONTEXT, except the last and second last arguments, all others must be of type String [], float [], or int []. Validation failed for the method buildBlocksAndGetValueByIndex defined in the Java class UDFNodePool.java. When the executionType is ALL_VALUES_OF_CONTEXT, except the last and second last arguments, all others must be of type String [], float [], or int [].

Can someone please suggest how this can be rectified? 

Thanks,

Nidhi Srivastava

entry.title: sap po sftp sender handle positional file with multiple header rows
entry.content:
Hi all,

Is it possible to convert a positional file containing multiple header rows using the standard FCC?

Below is an example of the file structure.

HeaderField1HeaderField2HeaderField3
DetailField1DetailField2DetailField3DetailField4DetailField5
DetailField1DetailField2DetailField3DetailField4DetailField5
DetailField1DetailField2DetailField3DetailField4DetailField5
HeaderField1HeaderField2HeaderField3
DetailField1DetailField2DetailField3DetailField4DetailField5
DetailField1DetailField2DetailField3DetailField4DetailField5


Please note that there may be multiple Detail rows associated with each Header row. In the example below, I expect the FCC to generate an xml with 2 subelements, the first one containing 1 header subelement and 3 detail subelements, the second one containing 1 header subelement and 2 detail subelements.

Thanks,

entry.title: Issue Migrating Integrations to SAP Integration Suite via "Migrate Process Orchestration Artifacts"
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I’m currently facing an issue while trying to migrate integrations from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite using the Migrate Process Orchestration Artifacts tool.

I have successfully configured the connection to the Process Orchestration System, and the connection test is successful. In Step 2 of the migration wizard, I can see and select the integration scenarios available in PO without any issues.

However, in the Pattern step, where I should be able to select an integration pattern, no options are displayed, as shown in the image below:

Has anyone in the community faced a similar issue? Are there any additional prerequisites or configurations required to have the integration patterns show up correctly in this step?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: The Future of SAP: Latest Trends Shaping the Industry in 2025
entry.content:
The SAP landscape is evolving rapidly. Here are the trends every aspiring consultant should know about:

1. AI & Machine Learning

AI is embedded in SAP solutions today. Consultants who understand AI-driven automation are highly sought after.

2. Cloud-First Deployments

S/4HANA Cloud is becoming standard. Cloud expertise is now a premium skill.

3. Sustainability & ESG Reporting

Organizations need consultants to help achieve ESG compliance. New specialization = new opportunities.

4. Low-Code/No-Code Solutions

Configuration skills are more valuable than ever. Rapid implementation is the new standard.

5. Cybersecurity & Data Privacy

Security expertise commands top dollar. Every project requires privacy compliance.

6. Real-Time Analytics

Business intelligence consultants are in high demand. Data storytelling is critical.

7. Extended Supply Chain Networks

Supply chain visibility is booming. Consultants here are building thriving careers.

8. Agile Methodologies

Waterfall is out. Agile, iterative approaches are the new normal.

The Bottom Line

The most valuable consultants in 2025 will specialize in these emerging areas. Don't just follow trends—master one and differentiate yourself.

Which trend excites you most? Which area do you want to specialize in? Drop your thoughts in the comments below!

Let's grow together in this dynamic industry. What's your next move? #                                                                                      #SAP #Trends2025 #CareerGrowth #SAPConsulting #AI #CloudComputing #DigitalTransformation

entry.title: MP: exception caught with cause com.sap.engine.services.jndi.persistent.exceptions720.Namespac in PI
entry.content:
Hello Experts,
We are facing an issue in SAP PI/PO where the message is processed successfully and delivered to the target system, but the sender receives an HTTP 500 error. In the logs we see the following:

MP: exception caught with cause com.sap.engine.services.jndi.persistent.exceptions720.NameNotFoundException: Object not found in lookup of NamespaceMapperBean.

Even though message delivery is successful, this exception still appears and causes the user to see a 500 Internal Server Error.

Could you please advise what could cause this..

Thank you

We are facing an issue in SAP PI/PO where the message is processed successfully and delivered to the target system, but the sender receives an HTTP 500 error. In the logs we see the following:

Even though message delivery is successful, this exception still appears and causes the user to see a 500 Internal Server Error.

entry.title: CPI HTTP Receiver always returns 400 “Syntax Error” although same JSON works in Postman
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

We are trying to call a BZSt REST endpoint from SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using the HTTP Receiver adapter. The goal is to send a small JSON request from our SAP backend to the German EVATR service and receive a validation response.

The same request (same URL, same JSON body, same token/parameters) works perfectly in Postman. In CPI, however, we consistently receive an HTTP 400 error from the target system.

The error message in the CPI log is:

org.apache.camel.component.ahc.AhcOperationFailedException:
HTTP operation failed invoking https://api.evatr.vies.bzst.de/app/v1/abfrage with statusCode: 400

 The response body from the server is an HTML error page:

<html>
<head>
<base href="/error_path/">
<title>400 Bad Request</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Bad Request</h1>
<p>The server detected a syntax error in your request.<br>
Check your request and all parameters.</p>

<p>Your request ID was: aSW1_biQek9iXbaem_MTxwAABZY</p>
</body>
</html>

In the meantime, we have tested quite a lot of variations. We tried many different header combinations, including explicitly setting headers like Content-Type, Accept, Host, and Content-Length, and we experimented with the “Allowed / Request Headers” setting of the HTTP Receiver adapter (including using *). None of these attempts changed the behavior – CPI still only seems to forward a very small set of headers, and additional headers set via a Content Modifier often do not appear in the actual outbound call (according to the HTTP_Receiver_Adapter_Request_Headers attachment).

We also experimented with the payload itself: different JSON formats, slightly modified test payloads, sending the exact same body as Postman, and even building a minimal iFlow where the JSON body is hard-coded in a Content Modifier and sent directly to the HTTP receiver. The result is always the same 400 response from the BZSt service, so it does not appear to be a simple syntax issue in the JSON itself.

What could be the reason for this behavior, and does anyone know how to resolve it or what else we should check?

Here is how the iFlow is built and the error messages:

entry.title: SAP PO: Empty Request Payload (REST to RFC)
entry.content:
Hi,

There is a requirement to send the request based from URL query params and map it to the target field via UDF, this is already working however I don't see any way to send empty payload as it is still looking for the source payload in Dummy Message Type even if it's not mapped to the target. If I add it it's working if not, I'm getting the following error response:

but If I added the source payload of the dummy message type it is working, although it's only dummy - it seems like it still requires it.

Can you anyone share what approach I can do to achieve the empty request payload?

Thank you!
